Award.AwardTitle: Investigating "Non-Complexity" As A Mechanism To Resist State Incorporation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Archaeologists have long sought to develop models to explain the rise of the state from contexts that had once been largely egalitarian. In contrast, the emergence of societies that are consciously opposed to centralized authority and were deliberately founded as "anti-state" communities have received relatively less attention. Dr. Darryl Wilkinson (University of Wisconsin-Madison) will lead a research team to undertake archaeological fieldwork in southeastern Peru, as part of a project intended to examine the foundation of a group of prehistoric societies that appear to have actively rejected the growing hegemony of the nascent Inca Empire. How and why did such communities seek to differentiate themselves from their more hierarchical neighbors? And given that they were eventually incorporated into the Inca State, why did their efforts ultimately fail? A desire to escape the impositions of centralized government, or to create an ideal community away from mainstream society, are phenomena encountered in the modern world no less than in prehistory. Studying the rejection of civilization (rather than just its rise and fall) will therefore contribute to a broader understanding of the diversity of political trajectories that human societies can take.

Dr. Wilkinson, working with local colleagues and a group of undergraduate students from the United States, will investigate the material culture of a series of settlements dating to the Andean Late Intermediate Period (c. 1000 - 1400 CE). These communities were established in the Amaybamba cloud forests of southern Peru, a region that was eventually conquered by the Incas, but which for a time seems to have offered a refuge for those seeking to evade their growing empire. Identifying communities that have made a deliberate choice to reject mainstream political developments normally relies on evidence taken from oral or written narratives. Such sources are not available for the Late Intermediate Period however, and so the primary goal of the project will be to generate empirically-grounded models for the recognition and analysis of anti-state communities where textual sources are absent. The research team will therefore carry out excavations and archaeological survey to produce data on architectural and artifactual remains, so as to permit a reconstruction of the everyday life of the prehistoric communities in question. Of particular interest will be the presence or absence of ceramic materials that are known to have had a role in hierarchical political ceremonies among closely-related communities living in the nearby highlands. This project will thus facilitate the modeling of anti-hierarchical communities in terms of their material culture, which can then be used in the comparative study of such societies on a global basis. Also, students from the United States working on the project will have an opportunity to gain research experience in a Latin American context, while also developing collegial relationships with Peruvian archaeologists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Unequal relationships between humans cannot exist without a basis in material things. In their studies of the origins of civilization, archaeologists have often examined the material artifacts upon which inequality and hierarchy are built. These typically include such phenomena as monumental architecture, elaborate tombs and objects made from exotic and precious materials. This project examined the reverse proposition; that people who wish to live in a consciously egalitarian fashion must actively dismantle the material basis for the distinctions between elites and non-elites. In other words, they need to suppress the production of things that support hierarchy and instead actively shape their artifactual world to suit the more equal society they hope to create. By studying a group of villages established in the southern Peruvian cloud forests during the period 1250-1450 CE, this project has demonstrated how prehistoric peoples in the Andes sought to establish “anarchist” or “anti-state” communities as a response to the rise of the Inca Empire.

The communities in question were established in the upper valley of the river Amaybamba, a tributary of the much larger Urubamba River. Through a series of excavations and archaeological surveys, the project was able to demonstrate that the pre-Inca populations of the Amaybamba region were originally from the highlands near Cusco, and had moved to the lowlands just around the time that the Inca Empire was starting to make its presence felt. The densely forested piedmont offered them a space of refuge; a place where the highland imperial state of the Incas could not follow (at least for time) and as such, permitted a bubble of relative egalitarianism and autonomy to survive up until the eventual Inca conquest of the piedmont in the later 1400s CE.

The inhabitants of the Amaybamba Valley seem to have suppressed hierarchy in two important ways. First, they created remarkably plain and undecorated pottery. Virtually every ceramic artifact uncovered in the excavations was devoid of any embellishments or adornments. It is a striking contrast to the  pottery one usually finds elsewhere in the Andes from this time period, which often has complex painted geometric patterns, or is shaped to resemble human bodies. These ceramic vessels were used in public feasting events, sponsored by the ambitious individuals who would eventually become the first Inca rulers. Their complete absence form the Amaybamba Valley speaks to the extent to which its occupants wanted to avoid those kinds of anti-egalitarian practices.

In the ancient Andes, feasting involved the dead as well as the living. Studying how the ancestral mummies of the Amaybamba communities were treated was therefore an important element of the project. Monopolizing the blessings of the ancestors by offering food and drink to their desiccated corpses was thus another way in which nascent elites sought to enhance their social standing. As a result, prior to the emergence of the Inca Empire we see ever more restricted access to tombs throughout the highlands—a process intended to increase elite control over the dead. Yet in the Amaybamba Valley, the opposite pattern was found. Tombs were dispersed across the landscape, and never closed off with walls, thereby rendering access to the dead more “democratic” and harder to monopolize.

Anarchism is a topic of growing interest in a wide range of scholarly disciplines, but it is still mostly examined through historical records or ethnographic accounts. This project instead offers an instance of ancient anarchism, focused on a time and place where no written texts existed. As such it provides a case study in one of the most common human responses to imperialism and growing hierarchy, but grounded in the analysis of everyday objects and practices, rather than words and ideas.
